title: US Macro Live, FOMC statement and Janet Yellen presser

teaser.title: US Macro Live, FOMC statement and Janet Yellen presser

bodyHTML:
6:59 pm
CG6:59pm

Hello!

CG7:00pm

Good afternoon Concerned T

MCK7:00pm

Howdy

7:00 pm
CG7:00pm

and Know when

CG7:00pm

We are live for the FOMC statement

CG7:01pm

and of course we'll be here throughout the presser starting at 2:30 as well

7:00 pm
AS7:01pm

No surprises on the amount of the hike, as Know When points out

CG7:01pm

okay, the statement is live

CG7:01pm

https://www.federa...tary/20161214a.htm

7:01 pm
CG7:01pm

"Near-term risks to the economic outlook appear roughly balanced."

AS7:01pm

They give a shout to the recent jump in break-evens:

CG7:01pm

Hi BBB

7:01 pm
AS7:02pm

Market-based measures of inflation compensation have moved up considerably but still are low; most survey-based measures of longer-term inflation expectations are little changed, on balance, in recent months.

CG7:02pm

break-evens always alex's pulse to quicken

MCK7:02pm

The projections https://www.federa...ojtabl20161214.pdf

7:02 pm
CG7:02pm

as expected, projected gdp this year and next is slightly higher

AS7:02pm

darn straight. BUT ARE THEY EXPECTATIONS OR COMPENSATION? (The answer: compensation demanded for expected inflation, so both, kind of?)

MCK7:02pm

Big move up in the dots, although not for the longer run

7:03 pm
CG7:03pm

longer-run estimate for the unemployment rate didn't move, curiously. It's still at 4.8

AS7:03pm

Also, no change in the statement about the balance sheet either:

AS7:03pm

The Committee is maintaining its existing policy of reinvesting principal payments from its holdings of agency debt and agency mortgage-backed securities in agency mortgage-backed securities and of rolling over maturing Treasury securities at auction, and it anticipates doing so until normalization of the level of the federal funds rate is well under way.

7:03 pm
CG7:04pm

Hi EAO

MCK7:04pm

Fed dots followed the market on the way down and it seems to be following them on the way up

AS7:04pm

though I don't think the banks are going to have to worry about the yield curve any time soon given the selloff EAO mentions

7:05 pm
AS7:05pm

(and agreed that liquidity in TIPS plays a role but seems like this time there are some fundamental drivers as well)

CG7:05pm

looks like most participants also want more than two hikes next year

CG7:06pm

the lonely dots are always amusing: one person wants six hikes

7:06 pm
MCK7:06pm

Also noteworthy that the economic projections for inflation and growth haven't budged despite tighter policy path. Score one for the monetary offset crowd.

CG7:06pm

In other words:

AS7:06pm

S&P 500 did one of those freak-out-then-pretend-like-nothing-happened moves

7:06 pm
CG7:06pm

https://twitter.com/LorcanRK/status/809112112261951488

CG7:07pm

This was priced in about as well as it could have been. Should we call this a communications win?

AS7:08pm

certainly -- it'll be interesting to see how the presser goes though

7:08 pm
CG7:08pm

wrwk_ec, who knows, mini-spike, then down, now about where it was before

AS7:09pm

wrwk_ec, seems like stocks were ready for this. i mean it was ... 100% priced into futures markets?

CG7:09pm

we're not near a bloomberg. if anyone can see what yields are doing, drop it in the comments

7:09 pm
MCK7:09pm

Communications win if the goal is to be 100% predictable

MCK7:10pm

There's an argument that excessive predictability is bad, in which case it's not a win

AS7:10pm

10-year's up for the day now, around 2.49%

7:10 pm
CG7:10pm

might still be a win for communications, a loss for policy, if that's the case

CG7:10pm

but actually

CG7:11pm

there's interesting restraint shown in the SEP

7:11 pm
CG7:11pm

other than moving up estimates for headline inflation this year from 1.3 to 1.5, just not much change

CG7:11pm

despite big fall recently in unemployment rate

CG7:11pm

i'm guessing the committee wants to be cautious about what'll happen with the new administration and congress

7:11 pm
CG7:12pm

thanks wrwk

CG7:13pm

here is something from goldman on fiscal policy and the fed:

CG7:13pm

Specifically, we look at the Fed’s response to tax increases in 1993, tax cuts in 2001 and 2003, and fiscal stimulus in 2009. We draw three conclusions. First, Fed staff updated their fiscal projections in real time, often before bills were even introduced, and had fully accounted for the impact of past packages by the time they became law. Second, FOMC participants updated their own fiscal expectations nearly as quickly. Third, participants began to cite fiscal policy changes in support of their views on appropriate monetary policy closer to the time the bills became law.

7:13 pm
MCK7:13pm

EAO I believe that might be their thinking but arguably taper tantrum was brilliant success of financial stability policy

AS7:14pm

as Pearkes points out on twitter the "belly of the curve" is getting hit

AS7:14pm

https://twitter.com/pearkes/status/809114065633210372

7:14 pm
CG7:14pm

the peril of monetary policy is that one can never know

CG7:15pm

"smashed" (love George)

CG7:15pm

bit more from GS:

7:15 pm
CG7:15pm

Many Fed officials appear to view major revisions to their projections in response to expectations of fiscal easing as premature. While we therefore expect FOMC participants to only modestly upgrade their GDP growth projections from 2% to 2.2% in 2017 and from 2% to 2.1% in 2018 and to leave the dots unchanged, our findings imply upside risk to these estimates.

MCK7:15pm

EAO, high cost to whom?

CG7:17pm

think maybe EAO means it's a big risk to take if economic agents interpret the unexpected move as representing a hawkish move?

7:17 pm
AS7:17pm

I suppose we should point out that the twitter account of PEOTUS still has no monetary-policy-related posts, which to me is the biggest uncertainty today

CG7:18pm

politicization of the Fed one of next year's biggest risks, I'd say

AS7:18pm

ha good point wrwk -- for that maybe keep an eye on Tesla stock instead??

7:19 pm
AS7:19pm

also EEM (emerging markets ETF) took a dive after the announcement. off 1.9% now

AS7:19pm

or 2%. that's the bit that's surprising to me, tbh. how were EM ETF traders not prepared for a hike??

MCK7:20pm

PEOTUS is in a meeting hoping to get some additional private capex

7:21 pm
AS7:22pm

someone (can't remember who, maybe Kara Swisher) mentioned that was a possible personality conflict -- seemed sensible, but I should really avoid any & all political analysis

CG7:22pm

projected rates path in the SEP now higher for next year (median from 1.1 at end of 2017 to 1.4), slightly higher in subsequent years

AS7:23pm

(yet another blow against the efficient-markets hypothesis, EAO)

7:23 pm
CG7:23pm

markets had moved towards Fed recent path recently, but not converged. now Fed moves away from markets again

MCK7:24pm

CG, markets have moved a lot since election, see these charts

https://twitter.com/M_C_Klein/status/809109131940470784

AS7:25pm

Mizuho economist Steven Ricchiuto says the market was expecting two 2017 hikes reflected in the dots, rather than three

7:26 pm
CG7:26pm

Indeed

MCK7:26pm

reminder that the press conference starts in 5 minutes and you can stream it from here https://www.federalreserve.gov/

AS7:26pm

so that probably helps explain some of it. spoos down 35 bps, the 10-year yield just crossed 2.5% level

7:29 pm
AS7:29pm

yep GS has been expecting the Fed to be more hawkish than the market for a while -- drives their bullish dollar call too

CG7:30pm

HERE WE GO

CG7:31pm

we are represented by Sam I AM Fleming

7:31 pm
CG7:31pm

at the presser, I mean

CG7:31pm

Yellen now speaking

CG7:31pm

Good tweet by this rando

7:31 pm
CG7:32pm

https://twitter.com/M_C_Klein/status/809116065485750272

MCK7:32pm

"my colleagues and I are recognizing the considerable progress the economy has made in our two objectives"

CG7:32pm

biz investment remains soft, she says

7:32 pm
AS7:32pm

my dollar data's a bit delayed, but I have it up 0.5% -- I'm particularly interested to see whether the USD slows down the whole US fiscally driven reflation thesis

MCK7:33pm

Yellen shouts out to consumer sentiment -- that's the "Trump bump"

MCK7:35pm

Yellen notes breakevens are up a lot, but still low

7:35 pm
CG7:36pm

survey based measures were always a bit higher, market based measures have moved in their direction

CG7:37pm

gdp a touch higher, unemployment a shade lower, the sun is a tad brighter, the night a bit cooler

AS7:37pm

hmmm not a trader bearbully, but the S&P's almost at 26 trailing P/E and almost at 20 forward P/E... (via S&P Cap IQ)

7:37 pm
MCK7:37pm

The error bars on the inflation projection are so narrow

AS7:38pm

just saw a real twitter rando call this hike "hawkish" but I am ... not convinced

MCK7:38pm

"Fed funds rate is only modestly below the neutral rate"

7:39 pm
AS7:39pm

https://twitter.com/wellisz/status/809120478451339265

MCK7:39pm

"Economic outlook is highly uncertain"

CG7:40pm

"Trump" - drink!

7:40 pm
MCK7:41pm

"This is a very modest adjustment in the path of the Federal Funds rate"

MCK7:41pm

@Ken average effective corp tax rate in the S&P these days is around 25% I believe

AS7:42pm

(assuming analysts use effective rates in their projections, so the sector impact might vary substantially)

7:42 pm
CG7:42pm

unexpected question from liesman this early in the presser, but not a bad one

AS7:00pm

Hi everyone

CG7:42pm

"tax policies can have that effect. it really depends on the specifics"

7:43 pm
CG7:43pm

liesman using a roundabout way to ask a question about politics, which she can't answer

MCK7:43pm

"Nothing I can say in general about what tax policy would do"

MCK7:44pm

"I can't tell you what the Fed's response would be to any policy changes"

7:43 pm
CG7:44pm

hence the bit about "non-productive capacity" targeted fiscal policy

CG7:44pm

yah, she can't start distinguishing now between tax cuts vs infrastructure growth (or whatever). Will come across as too political

AS7:45pm

on one side she mentions education/training/etc which calls for taxes, and then on the other she mentions investment/capital formation/etc which calls for lower taxes.

7:44 pm
AS7:45pm

summary: ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

MCK7:45pm

Next question: "What is the impact of these hikes on the average American?"

MCK7:45pm

I'm genuinely curious in the answer

7:46 pm
MCK7:46pm

So far Yellen saying it's a "vote of confidence in the economy" and "well-anticipated" therefore producing a "small effect"

AS7:46pm

(side note: some people's feeds seem to be quicker than others, but we're listening to the website broadcast. not sure who we have to pay/what order type is required to get to the front of the queue for the Fed feed)

CG7:46pm

Sam Fleming notes that unemployment rate is now below the long-run projection. Asks if there's a risk of Fed being behind the curve

7:46 pm
MCK7:46pm

This doesn't address broader question about what the hike actually does

AS7:47pm

I'd love the NeoFisherian response

AS7:47pm

ALL THAT INTEREST INCOME

7:47 pm
AS7:47pm

though in all seriousness, I'd be interested to see the ultimate effect of the steepening yield curve's impact on NIMs

AS7:47pm

if it's more lending, good news

MCK7:48pm

Unemployment forecast "just a few tenths below our estimate of longer run...not a substantial undershoot"

7:49 pm
MCK7:49pm

I wish someone would explicitly ask why unemployment below "neutral" pushes inflation rate faster

AS7:49pm

the rationale is that neutral rate is low but rates are lower, SRB

MCK7:50pm

Next question is about the room for fiscal stimulus

7:50 pm
CG7:50pm

mck, because they know the answer would be tautological

MCK7:51pm

"not obviously needed, but let me be careful that I'm not trying to provide advice"

CG7:51pm

question about high-pressure economy

7:51 pm
AS7:51pm

feels like she has used the word "Congress" about 10 times

CG7:51pm

hi boncoeur

AS7:52pm

(subtext: "nothing to see here PEOTUS no no don't mind us")

7:52 pm
MCK7:52pm

Good follow up here on the "high-pressure economy" idea

MCK7:52pm

Yellen now saying she didn't actually want a "high-pressure economy", just spitballing

MCK7:53pm

"an important research question"

7:52 pm
AS7:53pm

it's a "very important research question"

CG7:53pm

"I'm not trying to provide advice" =

I don't plan to give legislators any excuses to come after the Fed's independence

CG7:54pm

question about Trump's tweeting

7:54 pm
MCK7:54pm

"We don't want a persistent undershoot of unemployment"

CG7:55pm

further ducking political questions

CG7:55pm

Binya asking about Trump's plans for financial regulation

7:55 pm
CG7:56pm

Asks Yellen what advice she would give Trump

AS7:57pm

^ Yellen did clarify what they'd want fiscal policy to accomplish, by the way. in their view, productivity growth is needed more than employment growth etc etc

MCK7:57pm

"financial crisis took a huge toll on our economy...important to take a set of steps that would result in a safer and stronger financial system"

7:57 pm
CG7:57pm

Yellen "would advise... that it's important to look for ways to reduce regulatory burden on community banks and smaller institutions"

AS7:58pm

^ that's on Mnuchin's list of policy objectives as well

MCK7:58pm

does OneWest count as a community bank?

7:58 pm
MCK7:58pm

it is definitely "smaller" than some, at any rate

AS7:58pm

(also OMG you guys the 5-year yield has almost broken 2%, thx for the heads-up Boncoeur)

AS7:59pm

(not to get overly excited about round numbers, but it wasn't long ago that the 10-year had trouble holding the 2% level)

7:59 pm
MCK7:59pm

what's the 5yr TIPS yield?

AS8:00pm

that one's had a bit of a run, to 0.0889

AS8:01pm

5-year at 1.9893% (both via BBG's website, seem to be current)

8:01 pm
AS8:02pm

"wait and see" drink

AS8:04pm

(also a good q EAO. though if I remember correctly they do have access to the discount window which means Fed can act as LOLR if needed)

CG8:04pm

question about her current term, if wants another term

8:04 pm
CG8:04pm

she def won't answer this

AS8:04pm

(it's possible I'm wrong on that though EAO)

MCK8:05pm

Yellen says labor market looks like it does before the recession

8:05 pm
MCK8:05pm

That position is tough to defend given change in prime employment rate

AS8:05pm

yeah I was going to say MCK, that sounds kinda pollyanna-ish

CG8:05pm

yeah i don't buy it

8:06 pm
CG8:06pm

plus appalling wage growth that entire time

MCK8:07pm

Now we have a question on whether stocks are fairly valued or if they're a bubble. Note that the question was framed in terms of Dow points.

CG8:08pm

this presser has been a masterclass in questions to which Yellen can't respond, and consequently also a masterclass in how not to respond to questions

8:11 pm
AS8:11pm

(LOL at the Dow thing MCK. I assume everyone just wants to bring rally hats back into style)

CG8:11pm

Yellen sounds pained to keep her options open regarding running a high-pressure economy. I suspect she just doesn't know if it would work, but would nonetheless rather gently land at 2% rather than run hot

MCK8:11pm

Yellen continuing to be on the defensive about "high-pressure economy" as a potential solution to hysteresis

8:13 pm
MCK8:13pm

As some wags on Twitter have noted, pretty remarkable no one has asked about the dollar yet

CG8:13pm

right, she's not ready to commit to the idea. Maybe she thinks it was risky enough to give that speech questioning if it might work

CG8:14pm

right MCK, lots of questions about non-monpol issues, none about USD

8:14 pm
MCK8:14pm

Question about what policies could increase manufacturing employment

AS8:15pm

"I have not weighed in... I don't want to weigh in... I don't plan to weigh in" -- Yellen on fiscal policy

AS8:15pm

sheesh, give 'er a break guys

8:16 pm
AS8:16pm

I'm legit surprised by the magnitude of the response from the belly of the curve today, by the way. Might need to go hunt down positioning data...

MCK8:17pm

Question about when the Fed will start shrinking the balance sheet. This is a good one!

AS8:18pm

whoa S&P 500's off almost 1% now

8:19 pm
MCK8:19pm

"We have long planned to begin to allow the balance sheet to run off" but vague on specific timing

AS8:19pm

ZH says it's that magnitude of the rise in yields that's caused the turnaround in stocks, haven't heard anything concrete that would've sparked it in presser but we're a bit delayed...

MCK8:20pm

Question just now about whether election outcome demands economic rethink. Yellen pointing to concerns about inequality and median wage stagnation.

8:21 pm
CG8:21pm

aaaaand we're out\

AS8:21pm

that's fair I suppose, but the story til now was a rotation -- into stocks, out of bonds. now the story's RUN AND HIDE. or I guess MACRO TRADER MARGIN CALLS

AS8:21pm

^ that was entirely speculative, by the way

8:22 pm
CG8:22pm

so shares down, belly got "smashed"

MCK8:22pm

That felt shorter than previous ones

CG8:22pm

it was

8:22 pm
CG8:22pm

final thoughts?

AS8:23pm

just in from Gennadiy Goldberg at TD Securities, in response to a question about the 5yr selloff:

AS8:23pm

It appears that Yellen was prepared to run the economy “a little hot”, but with the Trump stimulus potentially pushing the economy a little too hot, the Fed is now suggesting the potential for more rate hikes. The Fed’s economic projections were little changed, which suggests that their policy reaction function has – this time in a more hawkish direction.

8:23 pm
CG8:24pm

She definitively smacked down any perceived commitment to testing a high-pressure economy; doesn't want to run an experiment. I think that's too bad, but in any case it ain't happening. To whatever extent that was priced in, so much for that.

CG8:25pm

Perception after her speech and subsequent comment by Fischer was that Brainard's views on this were making headway. Maybe they havve been, but not to the point where the Fed will act on them, not yet anyways. I suspect this will be a reinvigorated subject for economic research, but it won't influence the Fed anytime soon.

CG8:26pm

EAO, I'm referring specifically to the idea of allowing the economy to overheat temporarily, but deliberately, to repair damage the potential growth

8:26 pm
CG8:27pm

Yellen discussed this in a speech a couple of months ago, said it was worth more research, but just now said she wouldn't run an experiment to see if it's true

CG8:27pm

as, mck, main takeaways before we close up?

AS8:27pm

taking a look at the CFTC data, and looks like asset managers were as long as they've been all year in 5yr futures as of last week

8:28 pm
AS8:28pm

leveraged money short positions as high as they've been all year

AS8:28pm

... so maybe the hedge funds got a much-needed win this time around?

MCK8:30pm

I was intrigued by Yellen's reluctance to "provide advice" on how to improve productivity or boost growth. That seems like a subtle change from the past when she and Bernanke were more open about benefits of infrastructure spending etc.

She also made it pretty clear the forecast didn't contain any expectations about changes to fiscal policy, which in some ways makes the steeper rate path a bit surprising. You could argue (reasonably) that the Fed continues to converge to the markets and the steeper path is simply a reflection of that, but you could also argue the market is assuming pretty big stimulus. So there could be a bit of a disconnect. It may get resolved soon.

8:30 pm
AS8:30pm

(Boncoeur, just looking at the CFTC's reported net positions -- https://www.quandl...easury-Notes-TIFF)

AS8:34pm

To be honest, I'm still a little surprised at just how hawkish this was seen (one more hike next year than was priced in, and EEM drops more than 2%). I guess traders haven't adjusted as quickly as I thought they would to the new reflationary world we live in.

CG8:37pm

Okay everyone, thanks for hanging out! We are shutting down, and we'll see you next time.

7:42 pm
MCK7:42pm

Question: "Do business and individual tax cuts increase productive capacity of the economy?"
originalTitle: US Macro Live, FOMC statement and Janet Yellen presser
